entities: Panel on United Nations Peace Operations
summary:
Undertakes to ensure mandated tasks are appropriate to the situation on the ground; emphasizes that rules of engagement should be consistent with the operation's legal basis and support the mission's mandate.

Requests the Secretary-General to prepare a comprehensive operational doctrine for the military component of UN peacekeeping operations.

Stresses the need to improve the Secretariat's information gathering and analysis capacity.

Calls on all parties to work towards rapid deployment of peacekeeping operations within 30-90 days; welcomes the Secretary-General's intention to use these timelines to evaluate existing systems.

Welcomes proposals to create integrated mission task forces and urges the Secretary-General to pursue capabilities to improve UN planning and support.

Emphasizes addressing root causes of conflict, including through sustainable development and a democratic society; concurs that reducing poverty and achieving economic growth is a step towards conflict prevention.

Stresses the Secretary-General's role in conflict prevention and looks forward to his report; expresses willingness to consider using Council missions to determine potential threats to international peace and security.
The Security Council:
Recalls previous statements on conflict prevention and welcomes the Secretary-General's intention to send fact-finding missions to areas of tension. 
Recalls resolution 1296 on civilian protection and looks forward to a follow-up report. 
Reaffirms women's crucial role in conflict prevention, resolution, and post-conflict peace-building, and endorses mainstreaming gender perspectives in peacekeeping. 
Calls for full implementation of resolution 1325. 
Welcomes the Secretary-General's plan to strengthen UN peace-building capacity and requests related recommendations. 
Recognizes poverty reduction and economic growth as vital for peace-building success. 
Emphasizes effective coordination of disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration programmes and timely funding. 
Welcomes the Secretary-General's intention to clarify UN support for local rule of law and human rights institutions. 
Welcomes the Secretary-General's intention to conduct a needs assessment for drafting interim rules of criminal procedure.
